metadata.case_name: Bombay Union of Journalists & Ors. v. The Hindu, Bombay

facts.text: Salivateeswaran claimed to be a full time employee of The Hindu, Bombay.
On February 15, 1956, Salivateeswaran addressed a letter to the Managing Editor of The Hindu, Madras, intimating that he was proceeding to Europe on March 1, 1956.

On February 16, 1956, the Assistant Editor of The Hindu informed Salivateeswaran that even though he was not a full time employee, they could not allow frequent breaks in duties and would relieve him from March 1, 1956 if he proceeded to Europe.
By letter dated February 29, 1956, Salivateeswaran was informed by the Management that he ceased to be an employee of The Hindu from March 1, 1956.
After returning from Europe, on July 5, 1956, Salivateeswaran demanded reinstatement and treatment of absence as leave.
Management declined the demand.

Salivateeswaran filed application under s.17 of Bombay Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 45 of 1955, claiming Rs. 1,57,172-8-0 alleging wrongful termination amounting to retrenchment.
Management denied employment relationship and challenged jurisdiction of Authority under Act 45 of 1955 to decide disputed facts.
Authority rejected contention, holding competence to decide disputed questions.
Management filed petition under Art.32 Constitution; this Court upheld plea but dismissed petition as no fundamental right infringed (Kasturi and Sons Pvt. Ltd. v. Salivateeswaran).
Authority declined to proceed due to disputed facts.
The Hindu had office in Bombay since 1937; at material time, besides Salivateeswaran, nine employees: seven administrative, two journalists Venkateswaran and Tiwari.
Salivateeswaran and Venkateswaran were members of Bombay Union of Journalists; Tiwari was not.
Bombay Union of Journalists is a Trade Union open to all depending on journalism livelihood in Bombay, not a union of employees of The Hindu, Bombay.
By resolution dated August 16, 1956, Bombay Union supported Salivateeswaran's s.17 claim.

Between April 9-15, 1958, 225 members (not including Venkateswaran) wrote letters supporting Salivateeswaran's cause and requesting Union to approach State for reference under s.10(1)(c) Industrial Disputes Act.
Union claims letters were requisition for meeting, placed before adjourned General Body meeting on April 17, 1958, chaired by D.V. Nathan, resolving to support Salivateeswaran.
On April 25, 1958, Union wrote to Proprietor of The Hindu, Bombay to settle dispute.
The Hindu declined; Union approached Conciliation Officer.
Conciliation Officer held meetings, reported failure on December 5, 1958.

On February 9, 1959, State of Bombay referred dispute between The Hindu, Bombay and workman/working journalists over Salivateeswaran's demands (Rs.1,52,172-8-0) to Tribunal under s.12(5) ID Act read with s.3 Working Journalists Act.

The Hindu challenged reference on three grounds: (1) no industrial establishment in Bombay; (2) Salivateeswaran not working journalist employed by The Hindu; (3) no dispute between working journalists and management, merely individual dispute not supported by appreciable number of employees.
Tribunal rejected first two grounds, upheld third: individual dispute not supported by appreciable number.
Venkateswaran and Tiwari filed affidavits before Tribunal stating dispute was personal, they did not support or adopt it.

Evidence on April 17, 1958 resolution unsatisfactory: no agenda, minutes, notices; Mahatame's testimony unreliable; document Ext. U-86 altered year from 1959 to 1958; no mention in annual report, letters, etc.
After reference, Indian Federation of Working Journalists expressed support via letters in April 1959 and resolution July 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether the dispute between The Hindu, Bombay and Salivateeswaran is an industrial dispute under s.2(k) Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, or merely an individual dispute lacking support by union of employees of The Hindu or appreciable number of its employees.
Whether support by Bombay Union of Journalists (not union of The Hindu employees) or subsequent support converts individual dispute to industrial dispute.
Whether Tribunal had jurisdiction to adjudicate the reference.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dispute supported by Bombay Union of Journalists of which Salivateeswaran was member.
Supported by Venkateswaran and Tiwari, the only other journalist employees.
Dispute taken up by Indian Federation of Working Journalists after reference.
225 members' letters and April 17, 1958 resolution supported the cause.

respondent_arguments.text: No industrial establishment in Bombay; Salivateeswaran not employee/working journalist.
Individual dispute not supported by appreciable number of The Hindu employees; Bombay Union not union of its employees.
Resolution of April 17, 1958 fabricated; no proper notice, minutes, etc.
Venkateswaran and Tiwari did not support.

court_reasoning.text: A dispute between employer and single employee not per se industrial dispute unless taken up by union or appreciable number of workmen.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of ID Act contemplates disputes involving rights of workmen as class.

court_reasoning.text: Support by Bombay Union (not employees' union of The Hindu) does not convert to industrial dispute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Supporters must be directly/substantially interested as employees of same employer.

court_reasoning.text: No support by Venkateswaran/Tiwari; their affidavits deny support.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dispute remained individual at time of reference.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence of April 17 resolution unreliable/fabricated: no records, altered document, procedural irregularities.
Subsequent support after reference does not convert individual dispute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jurisdiction depends on existence at date of reference.

holdings.text: Individual dispute becomes industrial only if supported by union of employees of that employer or appreciable number of its employees before reference.
Support by general journalism union or non-employees insufficient.
Subsequent support/withdrawal does not affect jurisdiction based on date of reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kasturi and Sons Private Ltd. v. Salivateeswaran
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld plea on jurisdiction under s.17 Working Journalists Act but dismissed Art.32 petition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan
precedents_cited.relevance: Individual dispute not industrial unless supported by union/appreciable workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Newspapers Ltd. v. The State Industrial Tribunal, U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: ID Act excludes individual disputes unless supported by body/section of workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Workmen of Dimakuchi Tea Estate v. The Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate
precedents_cited.relevance: Tests for industrial dispute: real dispute; direct/substantial interest of parties.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Hindu v. The Working Journalists of the Hindu in Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Single Judge view on withdrawal of support; overruled.

precedents_cited.case_name: Working Journalists of the Hindu v. The Hindu
precedents_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction depends on dispute at date of reference, not subsequent withdrawal.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines industrial dispute; reference procedure; requires collective interest for individual disputes.

statutes_cited.name: Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Application for claims; linkage to ID Act references.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Industrial Tribunal's award rejecting the reference for lack of jurisdiction, as the dispute was an individual one between Salivateeswaran and The Hindu, Bombay, not supported by the union or appreciable number of its employees at the time of reference.

key_quotes.text: "a dispute between an employer and a single employee cannot per se be an industrial dispute, but it may become one if it is taken up by the Union or a number of workmen"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core test for converting individual to industrial dispute.

key_quotes.text: "the persons who seek to support the cause of a workman must themselves be directly and substantially interested in the dispute"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits support to employees of same employer.

key_quotes.text: "the jurisdiction of the labour court to proceed with the matter wholly depends on whether the industrial dispute referred to it for adjudication existed or was apprehended on the date of the reference"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Timing of support critical for jurisdiction.
